bibl.title: Letter from Blossom Reed to George A. Kellogg, October 18, 1941

div1.p: Blossom Reed informs Kellogg that she has been very ill. She discusses the photographs taken at the Cornwell painting unveiling and inquires about Kissinger's medical condition.

div1.head: Letter from Blossom Reed to George A. Kellogg, October 18, 1941
div1.opener:
Not having heard from her
since June 15th this
was of interest.
SalG.
Mrs. Blossom Reed
2810 - 36th Place,
North West
Washington, D. C.
October 18, 1941
Dear old George Kellogg-
div1.p:
Your letter with two newspaper pictures of the “Conquerors
of Yellow Fever” dated July 25 I had the pleasure of reading
yesterday, Oct. 17) What do you know! It seems that that
letter of yours arrived the day I was bodily picked up from
my bed at Blue Ridge and brought to the Walter Reed Hospital
where I stayed until Oct 9th. I certainly threw one “big fit”
a complete nervous collapse. Well, I dn't remember much
about it. Am feeling quite well now for one of my tender
years and my life has been taken over by my family, General
and Mrs. Reed, many doctors. I am not allowed to go back to
Blue Ridge but am to stay here, care free. Mother has been
a wonderful sport, staying in her cottage all summer. Of
course, the family going to see her, etc.

It seems now that I've “waked up” five years since my trip
to Cleveland. I have been allowed no mail, no visitors, for
so long. I could not be more stupid.

What of Kissinger? Just as well Mr. Law had that party when
he did, with Kissinger and myself “acting up” as we did.
Cleveland must be some town to mow the old folks down like it
did us. However, I remember Joe! and where are all the “firm”
that were so kind to me and were my body guards?

Mother is coming and stay with my brother here at 2810 for
the winter. Do come by Washington. I would love to see you
and your wife. As I am not allowed to go in any of the shops
for quite a while (I'm sure I could and enjoy it) I have decided
that I might give, if the plates have not been destroyed, some
of those pictures in Cleveland for Christmas presents. I have
two. You gave or sent me--I can't remember--The one I'd like
would be the one they brought me yesterday from Blue Ridge with
your letter. From left to right, Dean Cornwell, Dr. Hench, me,
looking very sad, and Kissinger. It's a fine picture of “The
Conquerors”. I have many of the newspaper ones from the Cleve-
land paper, you remember, to the doctors at the Walter Reed
and they were crazy about them. I've just been told about the
picture sent mother. Did any one ever thank who ever sent it?
If not, it's because the family have been nuts about me since
June.

If you will be good enough to send me the address in Cleveland
of the man who took the pictures, I will give you that drink I
promised when you were to come back for that hous party last
summer. God willing, next summer, and would you send me, please,
Dr. Hench's address. I would like to let him know that I am well
again. He was sweet while I was ice. I could never
answer a letter I had from him just before I was taken
ill. Perhaps from the length of this letter and my
writing so hard to read you may wish I had stayed a
little longer at the Walter Reed Hospital. Do let me
have some news of you and my old friends. I'll never
forget that wonderful trip. With my very best wishes
to you and your wife, Mr. Withington, Mr. Law, and
Dean Cornwell, Many thanks again,
